description.narrative:
The cross-sector movement is an informal coalition of unregistered networks and groups, supported by a small group of committed NGOs, including PAC and Oxfam partners United Sisterhood and AEC. The movement was initiated in 2011 around the proposed NGO Law (LANGO). In the draft, unregistered groups were particularly affected, limiting the Freedom of Association. The formal NGO sector did not seem willing to take up this issue at first, but in the end the two worked together. In 2012, the cross-sector movement organized events around Cambodia#s chair of ASEAN. After the initial ASEAN People#s Forum (APF) organizing committee was limited to formal NGOs in January 2012, the movement decided to organse its own ASEAN Grassroots People Assembly (AGPA) during the second summit in November 2012. The Assembly was a success in raising awareness on the (potential) importance of ASEAN for Cambodia and putting Cambodian issues on the international agenda. In spite of severe limitations by the authorities, the Assembly managed to take place and produceda Joint Statement.
In 2013, the obvious rallying point was the National Elections in July. The focus was on regional events to actively engage the grassroots, but also because so many events were taken place at national level already, including by NGO Forum. In the end regional events were held in the South (Sihanoukville), North (Siem Reap), and North West (Kampong Chhnang. The three main political parties accepted the AGPA statement in two of the three regions. Inthe aftermath of the 2013 elections a lot of internal discussions took place. Some members wanted to side with the opposition party. In the end, the movement reconfirmed its independent position. The first half of 2014 was used to reconfirm the guiding principles and membership criteria. Later in the year a series of workshops were organized in the regions on the Cambodian Constitution. As of March 2015, the membership of the movement is spread across four regions (Central including South East, South West, North and North West).The members vary between networks, local NGOs and single communities, a total of 9-12 per region.
In 2015, the Cross Sector movement will complete the workshops on the Cambodian Constitution, strengthen the movement at nationaland regional level and organise a National Assembly (Cambodia Grassroots People#s Assembly) in November 2015 focused on the ASEAN integration and opening of borders in 2016.

participating-org.narrative: People's Action for Change (PAC) is one of the Core Group members and contract holder for the Cross-sector movement, an informal coalition of grass roots networks and groups in Cambodia. The movement came up in 2010 during the development of the Law on NGOs (LANGO), which would have had very negative impact on unregistered organisations. In 2012 the movement organised the ASEAN Grassroots People's Assembly. In spite of severe restrictions imposed by the Cambodian government, people managed to meet an dissue a Joint Statement on the releance of ASEAN and highlighting the critical issues in present-day Cambodia.

mailing-address.narrative: PO box 30919, 2500 GX The Hague, The Netherlands

sector.narrative: The right to social and political participation

description.narrative: no. of cases revealing that globally linked citizens and globally operating partner organisations have strengthened their capacity to hold governments, businesses, international institutions and civil society organisation accountable for power abuse, corr
